references.B09DRA01USGP: Dragoo, J.W. 2009. Family Mephitidae (skunks). Pp. 532-563 in Handbook of the mammals of the world, vol. 1 Carnivores (D. E. Wilson and R. A. Mittermeier, eds.). Lynx Edicions. Barcelona, Spain

references.B74DAV01NAUS: Davis, W. B. 1974. The mammals of Texas. Texas Parks and Wildlife Dept., Bull. No. 41. 294 pp.

habitat_description: Conepatus leuconotus inhabits grasslands (Patton, 1974; Hoffmeister, 1986), deserts of succulents and grasses (Patton, 1974; Meaney et al., 2006), open woodlands (Hoffmeister and Goodpaster, 1954; Hoffmeister, 1986; Meaney et al., 2006), rocky canyons (Davis, 1974; Patton, 1974) brush of oak, mesquite, or chapparal (Hoffmeister and Goodpaster, 1954; Beasom, 1974; Patton, 1974; Shmidly and Hendricks, 1984; Meaney et al., 2006), pine-oak forest (Findley et al., 1975; Schmidly and Hendricks, 1984; Meaney et al., 2006), and pinyon pine woodlands (Caire et al., 1989; Fitzgerald et al., 1994). A compilation of data by Dragoo et al. (1988) revealed that the majority of documented captures were in brush or cactus. The species avoids open deserts and closed forests (Davis, 1945; Rosatte, 1987). Rarely observed at water sources, it is hypothesized that the hog-nosed skunk satisfies its water requirements through food (Patton, 1974; Dragoo and Sheffield, 2009). C. leuconotus has been observed from near sea level in Texas to elevations up to 9,000 ft. in Arizona (Hoffmeister, 1986).
